entry.title: Pashinyan suggests Russia appeals to UNSC if obligations can‚Äôt be met

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan suggests Russia appeals to UNSC if obligations can‚Äôt be met
media:group.media:description:
üìçArmenia and Azerbaijan entered a fourth round of talks over a peace treaty after Yerevan received new proposals from Baku. üìçArmenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan stated that Russia should appeal to the United Nations Security Council if it cannot fulfill its obligations to ensure security in Nagorno-Karabakh. üìç108,000-110,000 people from Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine have moved to Armenia since Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion of Ukraine last year, according to Economy Minister Vahan Kerobyan.
Credits: Ruptly

media:group.media:title: Armenia-Turkey - A thawing relationship?
media:group.media:description:
In late 2021, Armenia and Turkey appointed special envoys for talks, launching another round of normalization efforts. Consecutive Armenian and Turkish administrations have made their shots at securing a rapprochement, but to little effect. However, some analysts believe this time may be different. CivilNet‚Äôs team traveled to Istanbul last month to better understand Turkey‚Äôs perspective, Azerbaijan‚Äôs role in the process, and how the country‚Äôs upcoming general elections could shift foreign policy toward Armenia.
CivilNet traveled with a group of Armenian experts, who realized their visit to Turkey in the framework of the UK CSSF project - Engaging Society and Government in Armenia in Developing an Agenda for a Secure Region.

entry.title: Why does Aliyev portray Azerbaijan as a ‚Äòneutral actor‚Äô?

media:group.media:title: Why does Aliyev portray Azerbaijan as a ‚Äòneutral actor‚Äô?
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet host and analyst Eric Hacopian sat down with reporter Emilio Cricchio to discuss Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev‚Äôs remarks at a conference in Baku last week. Eric also talks about reports of recent protests in the Azerbaijani province of Saatli, what a post-Erdoƒüan Turkey could mean for Armenia, and if the ethnic cleansing of Nagorno-Karabakh‚Äôs Armenians would really be a ‚Äúred line‚Äù for the West.

entry.title: Ex-NATO chief lambasts Azerbaijan‚Äôs ‚Äòillegal‚Äô blockade of Nagorno-Karabakh

media:group.media:title: Ex-NATO chief lambasts Azerbaijan‚Äôs ‚Äòillegal‚Äô blockade of Nagorno-Karabakh
media:group.media:description:
The ethnic cleansing of Nagorno-Karabakh‚Äôs Armenians would be a ‚Äúred line‚Äù for the West, said former NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen during a meeting with Armenian reporters and policy experts Monday, including CivilNet Editor-in-Chief Karen Harutyunyan. After holding high-level talks with Armenia‚Äôs prime minister and other senior officials, Rasmussen visited the entrance of the Lachin corridor, the only overland route between Armenia and Nagorno-Karabakh, which Azerbaijan has blockaded for more than 90 days.
Credits: Ruptly
